short_reason: Popular uprising overthrowing dynasty; tax collectors targeted; reforms follow but episode is violent revolt.
Urban rebellion/civil conflict with withholding taxes; charter is outcome, not main arena.
Allied city-states vs Athens over tribute; escalates into interstate war dynamics.
Mass uprising over war taxes culminating in deposition of ruler.
Armed anti-imperial revolt against Persian fiscal extraction and temple seizures.
Mutiny plus peasant mobilization becomes prolonged armed war tied to taxation/arrears.
Rhodes-Byzantium war over maritime tolls resolved by treaty ending duties.
Riots/disorder around tax farming and coercive collection; episodic crowd contention dominates.
Formal petition/complaint about abusive grain-tax collection; no major riot or rebellion.
Imperial edict granting tax/corvée exemptions as incentives; explicitly not rebellion.
Focus is tax remission decrees and relief measures; policy enactment is central.
Smuggling/black-market oil sales to evade tax farm; clandestine evasion is core.
Court remonstrance and policy debate over taxes/corvée; institutional arena dominates.
Factional struggle forcing abdication with some popular mobilization; institutional power contest central.
Elite-led urban protest/deputation pressuring rulers over levies; public contentious episode.
Municipal tax refusal met by military capture/destruction; violent coercion and resistance dominate.
Urban rioting and arson against extraordinary tax; episodic uprising suppressed.
Armed uprising in Thebaid targeting Roman tax collectors; suppressed by governor.
Senatorial debate/obstruction over inheritance tax; formal legislative arena decisive.
Mass armed rebellion (Red Eyebrows) amid fiscal crisis; violence and overthrow central.
Sustained guerrilla insurgency against taxation/conscription with sieges and raids.
Conspiracy and armed revolt in Gaul against tribute and tax-driven debt; suppressed militarily.
Petitions escalate to executions of collectors, siege and battles over tribute levy.
Riots/uprisings obstructing land survey and registration; episodic disorder not sustained war.
Flight occurs but main episode is armed mountain defense and sieges against census taxation.
Mass assembly protest in Circus over new taxes; repressed violently; not institutional bargaining.
Collectors petition for relief and threaten resignation; administrative grievance channel dominates.
Emperor/Senate policy process yields edicts and legal remedies; institutional arena central.
Boudiccan mass uprising with battles and town burnings against Roman fiscal exactions.
Tax refusal escalates into full-scale armed war and sieges against Roman tribute system.
Provincial insurrection with military confrontation; taxation central grievance despite succession crisis.
Tax refusal escalates into uprising/riot and imperial suppression; violence central.
Armed uprising resisting increased fiscal extraction; suppressed by punitive campaigns.
Poll-tax evasion primarily via flight, village abandonment, avoiding tax rolls.
Elite-led revolt with urban uprising, siege, and ruler assassination; tax abuse central.
Land abandonment, migration, and status shifts used to escape land-tax burdens.
Census/tax revolt featuring usurpation, armed resistance, and siege of Alexandria.
Anti-census unrest becomes armed usurpation and prolonged civil war dynamics.
Usurpation backed by mobilized troops amid heavy-tax grievance; coercive conflict.
Armed territorial revolt against corrupt tax extraction; petitions secondary.
Armed rebellion/usurpation resisting tribute exactions; suppressed by imperial campaign.
Civic unrest and opposition to extraordinary taxation; not primarily institutional bargaining.
Tax burden facilitates armed anti-imperial warfare with battles and attempted capital assault.
Antioch street riot over new levies with statue desecration and arson.
Flight and status change to escape guild-based taxation; exit is core mechanism.
Bagaudae armed separatist insurgency with territorial control and parallel institutions.
Senatorial petition yields imperial constitution remitting arrears; formal institutional arena dominates.
Tribute refusal between polities triggers invasion and renegotiated higher payment.
Multiple peasant uprisings with attacks on officials driven by tax/corvée burdens.
Clerical intercession/petition secures debt release and tax relief without mass unrest.
Byzantine–Sasanian war over tribute demand/refusal ending in annual payments.
Faction-led demonstrations and street violence against coercive tax collection and extortion.
Nika Revolt centers on mass riots/arson over taxes and officials, not sustained insurgency.
Tax grievance drives secession inviting Persian intervention; ends with treaty and annual payments.
Clerical confrontation and moral pressure leads ruler to revoke church land tax.
Anti-tax riot culminates in lynching of tax official; episodic crowd violence.
Urban riot with register-burning and attacks on collectors over new levies.
Everyday clandestine evasion via register falsification and concealment; not public contention.
Blocking register revision resolved by royal arbitration confirming fiscal privilege; formal authority decisive.
Domestic tax grievance expressed by aiding invading polity in reconquest struggle between states.
Fiscal refusal triggers foreign-backed invasion and territorial seizure between polities.
Armed uprising directly against increased taxation and coercive collection.
State edicts and enforcement to close tax-exemption loopholes; not resister-led contention.
Court memorials and policy dispute over registration reform in formal institutions.
Militarized local resistance to imperial poll/census tax with killings and city seizures.
Tax resistance coupled with armed usurpation attempt and naval assault.
Violent attacks on tax collectors within civil war; armed resistance central.
Evasion via coordinated weights-and-measures manipulation to reduce tea tax.
Banditry and smuggling escalate into prolonged armed rural rebellion harming revenues.
Collective refusal with appeals seeking standardized obligations; negotiated redress dominates.
Armed uprising and refusal to pay kharaj against tax-farming enforcement.
Interstate war initiated by refusal to pay annual tribute.
Localized urban market riot over new market taxes and subsistence pressures.
Mountain guerrilla rebellion over tribute and service obligations; suppressed by force.
Peasant land-tax revolt with violence; external conquest follows as outcome.
Violent urban resistance to Danegeld collection and harsh royal repression.
Councils/charters and excommunication threats constrain exactions through formal authority.
Clerical petitioning and lobbying seek relief from neighbor-liability tax law.
Cash-tax reform sparks revolt with territorial seizures, sieges, and rival emperor.
Provincial rebellion against monetized service/tax reform; defection and armed resistance.
Symbolic public spectacle protesting tolls; episodic protest rather than institution-building.
Court lobbying by clergy yields partial repeal of crusade levy via institutions.
Collective nonpayment and noncooperation against extraordinary levy without armed violence.
Jurisdictional tithe-rights dispute resolved through litigation, arbitration, and charters.
Papal-judicial arbitration and compromise over tithe commutation and assessment.
Elite tax refusal culminates in charter imposing consent-to-tax limits (Magna Carta).
Sovereign decree grants broad noble tax exemptions; policy enactment not contention.
Manorial tax/labor dispute escalates from litigation to violent revolt and record destruction.
Elite collective refusal and bargaining forces crown tax relief through political institutions.
Corvée dispute pursued mainly through litigation and royal adjudication.
Tithe resistance via withholding, timing, and measurement manipulation; not mass protest or institutional tax-authorization dispute.
Tax liability contested and resolved through Parlement litigation and precedent-setting judicial decision.
Elite privilege conflict over exemptions pursued through legal-administrative status contests and regulation.
Island-wide violent insurrection targeting tax exactions and foreign fiscal-military rule.
Dominant tactic is mass flight/abandonment collapsing the tax base, with some uprisings secondary.
Collective refusal to pay forced loans leading to abandonment of levy; violence not central.
Collective clerical noncompliance with royal levies; primarily refusal rather than court-centered contest.
Constitutional consent crisis with petitions and Exchequer confrontation; institutional tax-authorization dispute dominates.
Papal–monarchical struggle over clerical taxation via bulls, sanctions, and legal coercion.
Feudal aid dispute handled through royal arbitration, commissions, and litigation rather than street action.
Constitutional remonstrance escalates to localized assault on emissary; episodic violence, not sustained rebellion.
Local uprising/disorder obstructing new crop tax; limited description of sustained armed campaign.
Peasant tax refusal escalates into armed uprising and open warfare, ending in battle defeat.
Confederation uses petitions, litigation, and negotiated compromise over marriage aid; little violence.
Provincial leagues/federation organized sustained reform campaign against wartime taxes.
Noble leagues coordinate resistance and bargaining for charters/refunds; durable collective organization central.
Dynastic revolt uses tax exemptions as inducements; fiscal action described mainly as elite policy tool.
Tax dispute centers on audit, transparency demands, petitions, and arbitration; limited uprising secondary.
Anti-collection riot with assaults on purveyors; episodic crowd violence over in-kind levies.
Armed rural insurgency against land revenue increases with guerrilla tactics and severe repression.
Collective petitioning and Parlement litigation define liability for feudal aids.
Mixed petitions/refusals plus violent expulsion of collectors; episodic resistance more than institutional settlement.
Popular protest with sporadic attacks on collectors/purveyors; no sustained rebellion or organized tax strike.
Estate bargaining and charter-based consent withholding; formal representative negotiation is decisive arena.
Complaints and official inquiry/audit into corrupt collection practices; nonviolent accountability focus.
Petition-based legal challenge to new salt tax seeking redress; no riot or armed action.
Council veto and legislative obstruction of direct tax; institutional decision-making dominates.
Uprisings occur, but resolution hinges on Estates bargaining and conditioned consent to taxes.
Revolutionary uprising overthrowing ruler driven by tax/loan grievances; high-intensity regime-change revolt.
Tax crisis managed through estates assemblies, conditional consent, and reform ordinance—formal institutional arena.
Riot, arson, and attacks on collectors; episodic urban violence more than sustained rebellion.
Armed confrontation and killings of tax-farming officials; sustained violent resistance.
Street riot destroying tax equipment; harsh suppression; no sustained insurgency described.
Repeated regional uprisings against Yuan taxes and corvée; rebellion pattern dominates.
Urban mob stormed government and lynched ruler over taxes; episodic crowd violence.
Tax refusal escalates to armed rebellion/civil war to defend fiscal privileges.
Mass armed peasant uprising linked to war taxation; battles and massacres.
Primary tactic is relocation/migration threat by saltmakers to evade taxes.
Elite revolt mobilizing retinues under fiscal slogan; rebellion rather than institutional dispute.
Tax revolt and secession in Aquitaine triggers renewal of Hundred Years’ War.
Urban riots with killings/looting over hearth and food taxes; not sustained insurgency.
Tax refusal escalates to sieges, battles, cannon use; regional civil war dynamics.
Harelle/Maillotins: mass riots, looting, mock king; repression follows.
Poll tax uprising with seizures, arson, strongpoints; large-scale armed revolt.
Durable remensa associations with syndics and long campaign; armed episode secondary.
Factional, organized Busca/Biga struggle over taxes with repeated mobilization and governance bids.
Dominant tactic is collective nonpayment and assembly renegotiation; no armed violence central.
Commoners petition imperial authority for redress against local tribute abuses; nonviolent.
Estates General ordinances and fiscal reform are central arena despite crowd intimidation.
Catasto debated and enforced through formal policy/assessment institutions; limited clerical resistance.
March, city entry, executions and looting; tax grievance incidental but episode is uprising.
Organized urban revolt expelling tax officials with repression; primarily public uprising episode.
Armed uprising/civil war against seigneurial dues; violence and militarization dominate.
Noble league fields armies, battles, burns tax records; coercive armed revolt.
Muscovy refuses Golden Horde tribute; armed standoff between polities ends overlordship.
Consent-to-tax dispute handled within States-General; no mass mobilization.
Tax collection dispute escalates to assassination and armed disorder; suppressed militarily.
Mass armed rising against subsidy with battle and later insurrection; repression and fines.
Planned armed peasant uprising to abolish tithes/dues; conspiratorial rebellion suppressed.
Bell-rung crowd attacks town hall over excise; short-lived urban revolt.
Mass uprising/protest central; Landtag bargaining present but secondary to contentious mobilization.
Tax revolt escalates to armed rival governance, killings, and military defeat.
Armed peasant war with sieges, pillage, and battles over tithes and levies.
Dominant tactic is refusal/noncompliance and petitions; only localized threats of rebellion.
Tax strike/nonpayment of tithes is core, despite occasional local uprisings.
Large armed rebel army seizes towns; tax grievances central though mixed with religion.
Urban uprising/protest with tax refusal; not framed as sustained insurgency.
Estates petition crown to revoke exemptions; formal assembly arena dominates.
Uprising and mass protest for consent-based taxation; limited detail on sustained warfare.
Regional mobilization with episodic armed obstruction and supplication; not sustained rebellion.
Armed rural uprising with counterinsurgency; taxation and centralization key grievances.
States/municipal authorities reject and renegotiate taxes; some evasion but institutional arena central.
Cortes withholds consent and obstructs subsidies; purely parliamentary bargaining.
Attacks on collectors and killings; rural-urban armed uprising over gabelle and taille.
Escalates to armed insurgency and siege of Exeter over sheep/wool tax.
Complaints/petitions trigger investigations and contract changes; no major riot or rebellion.
Parlement remonstrance/legal obstruction against taxes; institutional-juridical arena dominates.
Tax resistance becomes armed revolt/war with seizures, guerrilla, and battles.
Violent peasant uprising against labor exactions; collective armed action central.
Multi-year organized armed rebellion against arbitrary levies and collectors.
Primary mechanism is mass flight to evade census/tax registration, with some attacks.
Coordinated armed peasant rising over war taxes, dues, corvée, and tithes.
Nonpayment of tithes with intimidation; no sustained armed rebellion described.
Cortes–Crown bargaining over alcabala; institutional dispute with municipal obstruction.
Third-estate cahier challenges exemptions via estates/administration; institutional program central.
Durable league/union coordinates tax refusal, petitions, and self-defense over time.
Tax strike escalates into armed intimidation and jacquerie with severe repression.
Violent obstruction and killings of enforcement; decade-long rural insurgency.
Open rural armed rebellion over excises/customs, later co-opted by Catholic League.
Urban demonstrations/placards and threatened rioting against millones; not sustained rebellion.
League-based peasant movement with sustained organization; nonpayment central though civil-war factions involved.
Collective rural nonpayment of levy; explicitly nonviolent and resolved without bloodshed.
Uprisings/riots and obstruction dominate; petitions/negotiation present but secondary in episode.
Peasant armies, armed actions, defeats and massacres; taille grievance central.
Tax strike escalates into uprising with coercive repression and manhunts; violence central.
Armed attack annihilates tax-collection detachment; anti-imperial revolt with tax target.
Armed peasant mobilization, battles, threats on Vienna; taxes/dues core grievance.
Formal petition/legal appeal seeking equalized taxation; no major riot or armed conflict.
Described as uprisings/collective resistance against taxes and Robot; implies violent rebellion.
Open rural rebellion against wartime taxes, conscription, billeting; attacks on officials.
Celali armed insurgency resisting ad hoc taxes; sustained rural violence and disruption.
Urban riots and intimidation over sales tax; episodic crowd action plus negotiation.
Armed mobilization and battles; imperial suppression with burnings and executions.
Regional uprisings with attacks on collectors/offices against emergency taxes; violent contention.
Dominant mechanism is taxpayer flight/land abandonment shrinking tax base, alongside sporadic uprisings.
Mass flight and land abandonment to evade taxes; exit is primary tactic.
Rebel armies, sieges and battles; tax withholding present but armed conflict dominates.
Great Contract is parliamentary bargaining over taxation/prerogatives; institutional arena decisive.
Recurrent rural riots are central; evasion tactics present but crowd unrest emphasized.
Public unrest and violent incidents against excises/tolls; not sustained armed rebellion.
Mob siege/harassment of tax-farmer lodgings; episodic riot violence disrupting collection.
Armed uprising with sieges and open-field fighting; taxes and corvée among key targets.
Fiscal-centralization revolt becomes secession with foreign-backed war and sovereignty transfer.
Petition of Right is parliamentary-constitutional contest over taxation authority; institutional bargaining.
Bell-rung crowd mobilization, rioting and intimidation against elus/intendant; street action central.
Rumor-driven urban riot with sacking and symbolic attacks over feared new taxes.
Popular uprising against salt tax extension; arrests/executions indicate violent rebellion beyond protest.
Ship money resistance centered on legal test case and later parliamentary nullification.
Street riot with lynching linked to gabelle enforcement; episodic crowd violence.
Sustained multi-year peasant revolts with lethal violence and military repression; taxes central.
Escalates into organized armed insurgency targeting multiple taxes and collectors.
Primarily urban tax riots and demonstrations; secessionist revolt is broader outcome.
Armed attacks, hostage-taking, massacre, and repression over tax collection.
Large peasant army, territorial control, lynchings; sustained rebellion against gabelle.
Episodic urban riots disrupting excise enforcement; no sustained insurgency described.
Attack on excise office and public resistance; not sustained nonpayment campaign.
Armed uprisings and violent confrontations with enforcement troops over wartime taxes.
Tax refusal with riots and attacks, but framed as episodic unrest spreading locally.
Urban crowd mobilization led by assemblies; escalation noted but limited armed detail.
Bread-and-tax riot with arson, prison breaks, killings; urban insurrection episode.
Revolt escalates to armed resistance and separatist republic; tax grievance central.
Merchants’ petition/complaint to sovereign for customs relief; spectacle supports redress.
Salt Riot: mass petitions plus violent street riot, arson, lynchings.
Parlementary refusal to register edicts and legal remonstrances are decisive arena.
Petitions escalate to confederation, marches, rebel camps, then military suppression.
Systemic evasion via exemptions, bribery, underreporting, and clandestine export.
Copper Riot: mass marches, pillage, hostage-taking; suppressed as urban uprising.
Noncooperation escalates to armed bands, skirmishes, fortification; crushed militarily.
Described as regional uprising/riot quickly suppressed; limited sustained insurgency detail.
Urban protest spreads into rural insurgency with pillaging; ends with royal suppression.
Mass peasant uprising against gabelle spreading across provinces; attacks on collectors.
Armed bands, arson, coercion; tax grievance central though anti-feudal elements present.
Armed colonial insurrection with militia organization; taxes and duties among core grievances.
Uprising with coercion and violence over tribute/labor and alcabala enforcement.
Riots and disorder against hearth tax with petitions; contentious episode is riotous resistance.
Tax refusal becomes armed guerrilla insurgency; sustained violence central.
War of independence framed around extortionate taxation; sustained insurgency and territorial control.
Armed Cossack-peasant revolt against taxation and forced labor; suppressed by troops.
Indigenous armed rebellion against tribute and forced labor; regional insurgency.
Representative estates veto and bargain over new tax within formal legislative arena.
Mass march to castle with armed display; short-lived uprising, not sustained insurgency or pure nonpayment.
Quasi-military peasant units, seizures, attacks, and violent suppression over tribute and levies.
Smuggling, bribery, disguising bullion to evade stamping and export duties.
Petitions and lobbying aimed at Parliament; bill withdrawal is institutional arena despite some riots.
Episodic street rioting and mob violence against Gin Act excise and licensing.
Crowd violence, prison storming, lynching tied to excise enforcement; episodic riot not insurgency.
Mass rampage and property destruction forcing levy concession; protest/riot episode dominates.
Collective revolt against tax regime with severe exemplary repression; more than a simple riot.
Parlements/clergy block registration of vingtième via remonstrances and legal veto.
Week-long collective uprising signaled by temple bells; described as mass protest/uprising.
Inter-village coordination, attacks on officials/merchants, localized violence and military repression over exactions.
Multi-year regional insurgency resisting wartime levy; sustained rebellion beyond protest.
Anti-Cider Act riots, effigy burning, intimidation; episodic unrest rather than institutional contestation.
Complaints/petitions and negotiated relief to avert rebellion; unrest secondary to redress process.
Peasant uprising against levy and corvée with executions and mass repression.
Tax resistance escalates into militia formation and Revolutionary War armed conflict.
Urban insurrection: tax offices destroyed, palace siege, roadblocks, temporary control and later military restoration.
Stamp Act resistance centered on riots/intimidation forcing resignations; not sustained armed rebellion.
Strilekrigen: mass assembly, petitioning, riot in Bergen; suppressed by troops.
Regulators escalate from refusal/petitions to militia confrontation and battle (Alamance).
Urban riot triggered by census and anticipated taxes; intimidation and disorder dominate.
Primarily collective refusal/evasion of corvée obligations with petitions; violence not central.
Rising includes property destruction and repression; more than petitionary redress.
Tax refusal plus riots, prison storming, palace siege, temporary takeover; violent uprising.
Direct-action protest destroying taxed tea; key episode is contentious public action, not battle.
Large-scale military insurgency with sieges and battles; tax abolition central in manifestos.
Customhouse riot and obstruction with some petitions; street action is central.
Violent peasant uprising against Robot with sacking of mansions; pressure yields Urbarium reforms.
Riot/arson, attacks on tax agents, mass march; negotiated reduction then repression.
Storming and destroying aduana, armed street fighting, executions; anti-fiscal urban rebellion.
Escalated from petitions to armed revolt with killings targeting tribute collectors and colonial officials.
Mass intimidation and threats against customhouse; episodic uprising before merging into wider rebellion.
Large-scale armed uprising with battles and sieges explicitly against alcabala, tribute, and corregidores.
Mass uprising with armed confrontations and rebel council over taxes and monopolies.
Peasant riot with property destruction and castle march; not sustained insurgency.
Elite parliamentary/legal obstruction of taxes and surveys; institutional arena dominates.
Mob intimidation and humiliation of excise officer; episodic coercive riot-like action.
Armed peasant revolt with arson; includes anti-tax grievance though broader anti-feudal aims.
Aristocratic opposition blocks land tax via political leverage and noncooperation.
Armed insurgency obstructing courts and attempting arsenal seizure over tax/debt enforcement.
Collective petitions and commission-led redress; mobilization largely nonviolent and grievance-focused.
Mass uprising with attacks and defeating samurai units; taxes/levies central grievance.
Parlements/notables refuse tax registration; institutional veto central despite some unrest.
Elite-organized independence conspiracy around derrama; planned mobilization rather than actual riot/rebellion.
Tax noncompliance plus insurrectionary violence and attacks on tax apparatus within revolution.
Refusal of labor dues escalates to armed attacks on manors; suppressed by army.
Short mass uprising pressuring for tax exemption; rapid dispersal after concessions.
Robot strike and court boycott are central tactics, though some manor invasions occurred.
Prolonged armed insurgency with tax refusal as core grievance and target.
Mass village abandonment and cross-border flight collapses tax base; exit is dominant mechanism.
Sustained violent resistance to excise with armed mobs; suppressed by federal force.
Local crowd coercion detaining magistrates over taxes/conscription; episodic riot.
Armed mobilization and obstruction of assessors with prisoner rescue; treated as rebellion.
Crowd disrupts tax meeting and detains commissioners briefly; episodic protest.
Parliamentary repeal and ordered record destruction; institutional process is the event.
Tax refusal with violent resistance and arrests; more than simple petitionary complaint.
Violent attack on excisemen during enforcement; episodic anti-tax riot.
Parliamentary refusal and remonstrance over taxation powers; constitutional institutional arena dominates.
Estate petitions and assembly bargaining block tax equalization; institutional contest central.
Armed peasant insurrection with marches and destruction demanding suspension/abolition of multiple taxes.
Mass march, arson, office attacks; episodic crowd violence over taxes and prices.
Armed uprising with killings targeting tribute tax collection.
Tax repeal achieved through Parliament votes; petitions secondary to institutional arena.
Municipal resolutions/petitions and sovereignty claims centered on institutional control of treasury.
Rioting, fortification, guerrilla evasion and troop pursuit over taxes; ends with amnesty.
Urban uprising/mutiny against tax increases funding military reform.
Petitions, complaints, and audit against illegal levies; dismissal follows.
Elite privilege-based opposition via court lobbying/petitioning leading to repeal.
Urban uprising and continued protest against new poll tax under occupation.
Threatened/actual tax strike and nonpayment used as leverage in reform crisis.
Armed risings and open refusal to pay ferde during occupation/transition.
1834 armed revolts against tax reform and conscription; crushed by army.
Rural armed rebellion resisting new taxes, conscription, and corvée.
Repeated rural risings with suppression by troops; tax and corvée refusal central.
Guerrilla rebellion seizes capital; rejects tax officials; regime toppled.
Durable national league campaigns politically to repeal trade duties.
Sustained direct action destroying tollgates with armed presence; repression and reform follow.
Sustained tax refusal and petitions/litigation dominate; riots/revolts intermittent.
Local rebellions and occasional lethal attacks on collectors amid tax centralization.
Tax refusal backed by irregular forces and armed resistance yields de facto autonomy.
Escalates from court dispute to killings and peasant army; suppressed militarily.
From rent/tax default to violent attacks and arson; military suppression.
Millenarian armed insurgency over tax arrears/exactions; seizes estate, fights troops.
Budget defeat and ministry fall via parliamentary vote over tax shifts.
Armed peasant/indigenous rebellion against wartime taxes, levies, and land sales.
Urban insurrection with barricades and destruction of tax records; later reconquest.
Mass uprising/rioting in city over taxes and conscription; looting and arson.
Peasant rebellion with marches, sieges, improvised weapons against taxes and spahi dues.
Armed uprising against census/registration seen as tax/conscription precursor; suspensions won.
Labor strike and coordinated nonpayment; largely nonviolent noncooperation for tax rollback.
Mass assembly, intimidation, seizure of official; petitioning present but episode centers on contentious mobilization.
Violent anti-tax insurgency with yamen attacks, defenses, and city seizures by rebels.
Armed tax refusal with attacks on troops and governor; sustained rebellion cycles until suppression.
Collective nonpayment of bedel; coercive enforcement but no sustained armed rebellion described.
Tax refusal escalates to murders, militia-building, county seizure, and siege suppression.
Sectarian mob riot and massacre triggered amid tax resistance; episodic crowd violence dominates.
Coordinated estate nonpayment of per-capita levy; no riot/armed conflict, mainly refusal.
Petitions escalate to demonstrations, attacks, warehouse seizures and pillage; riot-like episode.
Parliament is decisive arena; petitions/delegations aim to defeat proposed excise in Commons.
Sustained coalition campaigning for fiscal reform; movement organization and agenda-setting central.
Peasant uprising against tax farming spreads as armed rebellion; later internationalized but domestic revolt core.
Long-term single-tax advocacy with leagues, candidates, lobbying; durable movement infrastructure.
Street rioting and sabotage over tram tax; refusal campaign present but riot is central.
Collectors killed in uprising against salt tax; violence central, beyond mere protest.
Petitions escalate to armed peasant force, office seizure, and clashes with state troops.
Covert organizing and armed attacks on colonial offices over head tax and corvée.
Urban mass rioting against new taxes; episodic disorder suppressed by force.
Popular uprising/unrest over heavy taxes; described as suppressed revolt without insurgent warfare details.
Elite parliamentary veto and cabinet fall over income tax; institutional arena dominates.
Customs-duty revolt leads to secession and treaty-based territorial transfer between states.
Legislative deadlock, provisional budgets, and negotiated reform; no mass resistance materialized.
Mass riots storming tax offices and yamen over surtaxes; widespread episodic unrest.
Poll-tax resistance escalates to armed anti-colonial rebellion with killings and counterinsurgency.
Coordinated tax strike and municipal noncooperation; protests occur but nonpayment is core tactic.
Mass demonstrations and tax nonpayment against colonial taxes/corvée; limited armed attempt secondary.
Salt-tax uprising with assaults on collectors and secret-society insurgent mobilization.
Night raid, killings, arson, record burning; evolves into multi-year guerrilla insurgency.
Petitions and obstruction/refusal under warlords; violence not central in description.
Electoral party organized around land value taxation; sustained movement politics.
Nationalist organization using tax boycotts and civil disobedience with periodic risings.
Coordinated nonpayment and noncooperation campaign; repression present but no sustained armed rebellion.
Militia-led sieges, assaults, and takeover of tax bureaus over taxes and corvée.
Includes prolonged rural uprisings and organized resistance; exit and petitions secondary.
Escalates from marches to seizure of authority and parallel governance under repression.
Dominant tactic is organized nonpayment and disruption of tax sales (‘dollar sales’).
Armed attack, expulsion of troops, autonomy declaration, and revenue seizure over surtax/opium.
Episodic riots: arson, storming offices, burning records; not sustained insurgency.
Fuel-tax strike escalated into major urban riot and street fighting.
Satyagraha and organized nonpayment against canal levy; petitions/inquiry secondary.
Armed uprising with sieges, ambushes, guerrilla tactics against direct land taxation.
Primary arena is Diet budget/legislation obstruction and stalemate over tax reform.
Durable movement (UDCA) built around audit resistance and electoral party breakthrough.
Tax revolt mainly via courts, commissions, and legislative anti-avoidance reforms.
Armed attacks and battles over land tax increases; some flight but violence central.
Core tactics are underreporting and bribery to evade agricultural tax; lobbying secondary.
Tax revolt escalates to insurrection and military suppression; petitions were initial.
Symbolic tax-day demonstrations; public protest without sustained nonpayment campaign.
Tax increase defeated through referendums and budget process; institutional channel dominates.
Ballot initiative constitutional amendment constraining taxation—formal institutional mechanism.
Mass marches escalated into riot and clashes; protest episode central.
Violent crowd attacks on offices/homes over fees; episodic riot with concessions.
Sustained advocacy campaign by taxpayer federation using petitions, ads, rallies, pressure.
Fuel-tax hike triggered mass protests, riots, looting, arson, and emergency measures.
Mass protest stormed government building; violent confrontation after police dispersal.
Large rural riot ransacking offices and homes; diffusion but not sustained insurgency.
Blockades/strikes disrupting fuel distribution to force tax relief; not armed rebellion.
Ongoing organized advocacy linking taxes to representation; legislation/litigation plus mobilization.
Separatist organizations mobilize around fiscal extraction and transfers; durable movement politics.
Capitol protest with intimidation and minor violence pressured legislature to drop income tax.
Business strike with street demonstration; episodic protest rather than sustained movement.
Constitutional ‘taxation without representation’ dispute pursued via formal petition to metropolitan authorities.
